body: This is a much better solution. Well played @lzybkr like it!
Recently I played with this and it seems like it might be too expensive  due to IntelliSense.
@iSazonov What is to expensive?

So two new overloads for ValidateSetAttribute:
```c#
ValidateSetAttribute(ScriptBlock sb)
```
and
```c#
ValidateSetAttribute(IValidateSetGenerator g)
```
IValidateSetGenerator vs IValidateSetEnumerator ?

@iSazonov maybe even **IDynamicValidateSet**?

Edit: Upon reflection I prefer **IValidateSetEnumerator**
It looks like it is from DynamicParams but it is not related directly. Also we have RFC for Dynamic Keywords so we should avoid "Dynamic" term to eliminate confusion.

@lfshr - C# requires `typeof(MyValidateSetGenerator)` because `MyValidateSetGenerator` is not an expression.

The interface name should probably not end in `Enumerator` because the interface does not define an enumerator.
Maybe IValidateSetValuesGetter
@lzybkr Sorry. Idiot moment.
I agree with @lzybkr, something like `IValidateSetGenerator` is a good shout.

Is this still up for grabs? I'm looking for something small to start with.

update: never mind, I see the PR is in progress :)
Welcome to code review!

maybe you can help me out with my challange. I like to set ValidateSet to run my "example.ps1 -region eu-cental-1" and get the AWS regions

Eg:
`Param(`
`    [parameter(Mandatory=$true)]`
`    [ValidateSet((Get-AWSRegion).region)]`
`    [String[]]`
`    $region`
`)`

`process {`
`# do whatever`
`}`

I don't see any link to the relevant PR, but it appears to need a script block, so you would write:
```
[ValidateSet({ (Get-AwsRegion).Region })]
```

you're right; it's not a PR; just a little script to automate my AWS stuff. Maybe I open one once it has some relevant features. 

> [ValidateSet({ (Get-AwsRegion).Region })]

this does not make any difference unfortunately
@lzybkr a PR is mentioned in this thread, but I don't see any links to it. Did this end up getting implemented?

You need to implement `IValidateSetValuesGenerator`. See:
https://github.com/iSazonov/PowerShell/blob/65349de2b25022092213d86cfc1f5dfe0c92cbc6/test/powershell/Language/Classes/Scripting.Classes.Attributes.Tests.ps1#L273

@rafaelc81 see here for the example that was merged into documentation after the PR was merged. 

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-Docs/pull/3133/files?short_path=8b392e6#diff-8b392e69e97629458a3c80ee54386057

The example in the docs looks nothing like the example the OP of this issue wanted. The OP asks for a script block, and the solution provided is a full on syntax-verbose class.

I can't get an example like the script block to work. Was that implemented or only the syntax-verbose class version?

If not, are there any plans to support the significantly more terse syntax? Should another issue be opened?

Thanks!

@OlsonDev The issue description is misleading. We only implemented a variant based on `IValidateSetValuesGenerator` interface until we receive more feedback. Feel free open new issue with the description of the necessary feature.

Indeed. It should be possible to borrow portions of the code from `[ArgumentCompleter()]` for this purpose; it also takes a script block and apparently applies it to the method defined in `IArgumentCompleter`
@vexx32 There is samples in attributes.cs file how to use execution context. I assume that the tests will be most of this work and not the code itself. :-)
@iSazonov @vexx32 Thanks, I created [the aforementioned issue here](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/8651).
